article text: ScienceHow ChatGPT and other new AI tools are being used by lawyers, architects and codersABC Science / By technology reporter James PurtillPosted¬†Tue 24 Jan 2023 at 2:30pmTuesday 24 Jan 2023 at 2:30pmTue 24 Jan 2023 at 2:30pm We asked¬†the AI tool Midjourney to generate this¬†image of a small robot on an office desk.(Supplied: Midjourney/James Purtill)abc.net.au/news/chatgpt-midjourney-generative-ai-and-future-of-work/101882580Copy linkLink copiedShareShare articleWhile schools are banning ChatGPT, Australian workplaces are already deploying it and other new kinds of artificial intelligence (AI) tools.For these tech¬†companies, law firms and architecture¬†practices, AI isn't just the future of work ‚Äî¬†it's already here.Launched at the end of November last year, ChatGPT¬†is known as a generative AI, or an algorithm¬†that can be used to make content. It¬†generates text responses to text¬†prompts,¬†like a very advanced chatbot.¬†Other generative AI tools make other kinds of content, like audio, images¬†and video. Many have launched in just the past six months.Queensland joins NSW in banning ChatGPT in public schoolsIt's been described as akin to students outsourcing their homework to robots.Read moreFor schools, universities and other educational institutions, the recent emergence of these programs¬†poses¬†the risk that students will ask a machine to write their essays or complete their assignment questions, rather than doing the work themselves.Some have decided to ban ChatGPT. But¬†experts¬†say this is the wrong approach, and¬†students need to learn how to effectively use these tools¬†in order to be employable graduates.In the midst of this debate,¬†Australian workplaces have been quietly experimenting with generative AI.Many who spoke with the ABC say that within a few years ‚Äî¬†by the time today's students graduate ‚Äî¬†these new tools will be¬†essential parts of the white-collar workplace, as much a feature of the office¬†as dusty keyboards, water coolers¬†and small potted cacti.Here's how they're using them.The architecture practiceArchitects at¬†the large Melbourne design practice Gray Puksand use¬†an AI tool named Midjourney,¬†which creates complex images from textual descriptions, using similar technology to ChatGPT.Images like this one: Architects are using images like this to spark their imaginations.(Supplied: Midjourney/Gray Puksand)Midjourney produced this from the text prompt:¬†"low rise parametric building biophilic reference sheet 3d plans sections elevations construction details annotations callouts axis dimensions visual coding".Jeames Hanley,¬†the practice's digital technology manager, said dozens of architects were using the tool¬†to¬†quickly realise and explore visual ideas."We have a paid subscription to Midjourney ‚Äî¬†we have 40 staff using it in a shared thread," he said."We are seeing the¬†architects' imaginations being¬†expanded as they can so much more easily visualise the design they are thinking of."Asked to create a plan¬†for a 100-person office space with desks, focus rooms, meetings rooms and board rooms, plus plants and lots of light, Midjourney¬†produced these¬†variations: They're nowhere close to the finished architectural plan, but these images¬†help with the process of design.(Supplied: Midjourney/Gray Puksand)Although Midjourney is older than ChatGPT, it's still relatively new. A San Francisco start-up of the same name launched it in mid-2022, and has been beta-testing and updating it since."I don't think it's¬†going to replace anyone, but in terms of efficiency it's¬†going to change our industry,"¬†Mr Hanley said."Some of our staff will be freed up to work more on the work that excites them,¬†which is the design."The law firmLast week, Sunshine Coast litigator¬†Kyle Kimball¬†turned to an AI program¬†for help."People¬†ring up and say, 'this has happened. Have I got a case?' I have to explain, 'it's not that simple. We don't know all the evidence.'"Which of these artworks were created using AI?We put an AI image generator and a human illustrator head-to-head.Read moreSo he asked ChatGPT to write an explanation, using the analogy of a doctor ordering an MRI and blood tests to diagnose the patient.The result was good enough to use, he said.As an experiment, he also recently asked ChatGPT to draft a statement of claim based on the 1992 Mabo case, and was impressed."If I'd asked a first-year lawyer to do it, it wouldn't have been anywhere as good," he said.Mr Kimball manages a firm of nine lawyers¬†based on the Sunshine Coast and in Sydney.ChatGPT's work¬†contained factual errors and had to be carefully checked, but then so did¬†the work of¬†junior lawyers, he said."Find me a person that you're paying to do a job that does the job 100 per cent accurately all of the time, and in the time this machine does it in," he said."I think it's¬†very exciting." Generated from the prompt: "a small secluded architectural space made of glass that reflects its surrounds of a mildly lit forest with tree canopy overhead and leaves falling cinematic."(Supplied: Midjourney/Gray Puksand)At the¬†law firm Piper Alderman, chief operating officer Chris McLean has also been experimenting with ChatGPT."There are lots of things in law it's not anywhere near ready for," he said.AI tool can pass medical school examsNow, with the first term¬†just weeks away,¬†educators are scrambling to rethink how they assess students.Read moreFor instance, it wasn't ready to give¬†complex advice to clients, he said, but might be used to write case summaries for lawyers."For¬†high-volume things like drafting wills and¬†conveyancing, it would be incredibly useful," he said.Belgian start-up Clausebase has already developed contract drafting software and has recently been beta-testing a ChatGPT-powered module.The consensus of feedback was that the tool¬†was useful, but imperfect, said Senne Mennes, the company's co-founder.Lawyers¬†needed to do a lot of work to check and "clean up" the work, but¬†ultimately saved time."One person phrased it very beautifully. He said, 'I already have the chisel and GPT gives you the marble when you don't have any.'"The events platformFor the past couple weeks, Melbourne¬†start-up Muso has been using ChatGPT to embellish the prose on its live-entertainment booking platform.Every month, the platform hosts thousands of ads for gigs: for each, the venue must write a brief description of the event.Often, this description was terrible, said Simon Raik-Allen, Muso's chief technology officer."They write something like, 'great cover guy coming.'¬†They haven't got time to do much else," he said.¬† Generated from the prompt: "copper style exoskeleton facade structure free flowing layered in a busy Sydney street with cars and people rushing past cinematic".(Supplied: Midjourney/Gray Puksand)The volume of bookings¬†was¬†so high that any human copy writer tasked with fixing the prose would have been immediately swamped.Now, a ChatGPT-powered tool embedded¬†within the booking platform¬†generates the copy, based on whatever facts the venue chooses to provide.From the input "weekly trivia at the Railway Hotel", it produced this description:"Come join us every week at the Railway Hotel for a Trivia Night! Put your knowledge to the test while sipping drinks and enjoying good company. Whether you‚Äôre a trivia veteran or a rookie, everyone is welcome. We'll provide the questions, and you bring your sharpest wit and the most challenging answers. So come join us in a relaxing and friendly atmosphere, and see who can come out on top!"It's not poetry, but it's good enough for an event listing."It saves [the venue] time and encourages more people to come to the gig," Mr Raik-Allen said.The software developerIn Melbourne, computer science student Riley Underwood has been using ChatGPT to write code and help engineer software.Previously, when faced with a coding problem, he'd go to Google and find links to potential solutions.¬†"Now I don't go to Google. I'll go straight to GPT," he said.Mr Underwood asks ChatGPT to write code, and uses its response as a guide."You¬†have to have a bit of experience to say this is 90 per cent¬†correct, and I have to make adjustments¬†to it."But, as with drafting legal documents, this process of editing is still more efficient than writing code from scratch."I would say there's probably a 30‚Äì40 per cent increase in productivity," he said.Mr Underwood and his business partner, Vance Chao, recently created a ChatGPT-powered tool that generates 250-word¬†property listings from property facts¬†for use in the real estate industry.In some scenarios, ChatGPT can turn half a day of coding into two minutes' work, Mr Chao said."It's a lot easier to read something that someone's given you and say it's wrong or say it's right than it is come up with it by yourself," he said.Steve Nouri, a Sydney data scientist whose titles include "chief data evangelist" for an Israeli tech company, broadly agreed with this assessment."I'm understanding the limitations before introducing it to a pipeline of software development," he said.But he noted that many "junior developers" were using it already."It's¬†100 per cent quicker than writing code from scratch."The¬†creep of AI into everyday productsFor the moment, generative AI tools tend to be restricted to discrete products, like ChatGPT or Midjourney.But increasingly these products will merge with other pieces of existing technology, and be harder to disentangle.ABC Science on YouTubeWant more science ‚Äî plus health, environment, tech and more? Subscribe to our channel.Read moreMicrosoft and OpenAI, the San Francisco-based maker of ChatGPT, are working on a ChatGPT-powered Bing search engine, while Google is reportedly looking to launch an AI search chatbot.Meanwhile, use of generative AI tools will probably become more expensive. For the moment, ChatGPT can be used for free, but OpenAI has plans to make users pay.The present may turn out to be a golden era of free access to powerful generative AI, followed by a period in which start-ups try to monetise their products."I reckon that¬†once they get out of trial, they're going to radically jack up the price," said Muso's Simon Raik-Allen."It'll be a huge money spinner and probably won't be available to every regular person because of the cost."Even so, given the enthusiasm of its early adopters, and the apparent boost to productivity, it's easy to imagine workplaces will pay for access.And if they do, they'll be asking for graduates that know how to use these tools.At¬†Gray Puksand architects in Melbourne,¬†Jeames Hanley repeated a quote he'd read somewhere on Twitter."It goes along the lines of: We won't be replaced by AI, but we will be replaced by people who use AI."Posted¬†24 Jan 202324 Jan 2023Tue 24 Jan 2023 at 2:30pmShareCopy linkFacebookX¬†(formerly¬†Twitter)Related StoriesWe challenged an AI image generator and a human illustrator. How real estate agents put artificial intelligence to work

Posted by Amy Platero | Jan 23, 2023 | Fundamentals, Real Estate, Your Practice | 3 




Ôªø
In an industry as face-to-face as real estate, an agent‚Äôs use of artificial intelligence (AI) to automate their work might seem like science fiction. But with recent breakthroughs in machine learning, that fiction has quickly become reality for tech-savvy agents.
ChatGPT is a chatbot which uses machine learning algorithms ‚Äî programming ‚Äî to understand written language and then generate responses based on user inputs ‚Äî your chat entries. OpenAI launched ChatGPT in November 2022 and is free to use during a research preview period.
The language processing model has galvanized technophiles across industries, including real estate.
Specifically, real estate agents use ChatGPT to craft compelling listing descriptions and content to automate their marketing efforts, such as social media posts, blogs and emails. This tool streamlines agents‚Äô more tedious copywriting and content creation tasks.
Read ahead for tips on how to use this revolutionary productivity tool.
Use ChatGPT to help market listings
While property photos do much of the heavy lifting in selling real estate, a well-written listing description also has the power to make or break a prospective buyer‚Äôs perception of the property ‚Äî and the agent.
An agent knows how to highlight a property‚Äôs standout features and ultimately sell. But to captivate the reader and make the listing feel like home requires fine wordsmithery. At minimum, listing descriptions sell best when they are short, free of errors and contain clear language with plain meaning.
It might take an agent 30 minutes to write and edit a listing description that effectively displays the property‚Äôs amenities and features. ChatGPT does it on command in seconds.
Example: listing descriptions
To produce a listing description, the agent needs to provide ChatGPT some written instruction and context. For example, when a user prompts the following:
A listing description for a 3 bedroom 2 bathroom 1500 square foot home in Sacramento, California with a 2 car garage and granite countertops. 
ChatGPT responds:
This 3 bedroom, 2 bathroom home in Sacramento, California boasts a spacious and well-appointed open concept living and dining area with large windows and natural light. The kitchen is a chef‚Äôs dream with granite countertops, ample storage and modern appliances. The bedrooms are located on the opposite side of the home, with ample closet space and natural light. The master bedroom features an en-suite bathroom with dual sinks and granite countertops. Additionally, this property features a 2-car garage. This home offers the perfect combination of style, comfort, and functionality. Don‚Äôt miss out on the chance to make it yours!
As you may have noticed, the AI added extra features not named in the initial request. Agents always need to examine the response for accuracy ‚Äî OpenAI warns the large language model is still under development and may generate incorrect information.
Additionally, all AI models are liable to inherit the biases of their creators and the data on which they are trained. Whether an honest mistake by an agent or a chatbot, discrimination in real estate advertising carries steep penalties. Agents need to review responses for outdated language like ‚Äúmaster bedroom‚Äù ¬†in the example above.
Fine-tuning the chatbot with more specific detail about the property‚Äôs features produces the best listing descriptions. For instance, when prompted with additional home features:
A listing description for a 4 bedroom 2 bathroom newly remodeled home with vaulted ceilings, a large backyard, and new windows in San Diego, California.
ChatGPT delivers a more detailed listing description:
This newly remodeled 4 bedroom, 2 bathroom home in San Diego, California boasts a bright and open floor plan with vaulted ceilings throughout. The home has been fully updated with new windows that allows plenty of natural light to flood the interior spaces. The kitchen has been completely remodeled with new appliances, cabinetry and countertops, perfect for any home chef. Each of the 4 bedrooms offer ample space and comfort, providing the perfect oasis for rest and relaxation. 
The property has a large backyard, perfect for entertaining, relaxing or enjoying the beautiful San Diego weather. A great space for hosting BBQs and gatherings with friends and family. 
The home‚Äôs central location provides easy access to all San Diego has to offer, from world-renowned beaches to delicious dining and nightlife options. Whether you‚Äôre looking for an investment property or a place to call home, this newly remodeled home is a must-see!
At its best, the chatbot gives an agent compelling copy to flaunt those new windows, vaulted ceilings and expansive backyard. The property, by the chatbot‚Äôs clever sleight of language, is imbued with personality.

Emerging tech for real estate agents in 2022

Social media
Real estate agents are also incorporating AI writing algorithms such as ChatGPT to curate their online presence.
An agent‚Äôs digital marketing strategy might include content for:

social media platforms;
blogs;
email; and
their real estate agent website.

Social media is the premiere ecosystem agents use to stay visible and strengthen their personal brand with clients. Real estate agents know the importance of soliciting new clients and keeping tabs on past clients.
Popular social media sites for agents include:

Facebook;
Instagram;
TikTok;
LinkedIn;
Pinterest; and
YouTube.

Some sites are more text-based (Facebook and LinkedIn), image-based (Instagram and Pinterest) and others are video-based (TikTok and YouTube).
An agent uses ChatGPT to create social media content by prompting the chatbot to:

generate ideas for promotional content related to your brand;
write content tailored to target formats and audiences; and
refine and expand that content with additional prompts.

Related article:
Career Coach: digital marketing

Example: social media
An agent might write the chatbot the following command:
Ideas for social media posts for agents.
ChatGPT‚Äôs response:

Share testimonials and success stories from satisfied clients
Offer helpful tips and advice for buying or selling a home
Share photos and virtual tours of your current listings
Share local market updates and statistics
Promote open houses and upcoming events
Share helpful resources such as home buying/selling guides
Share your own personal story and why you became a real estate agent
Showcase your community involvement and local partnerships
Share industry news and updates
Showcase your team and highlight their accomplishments

When the agent decides to use one of these ideas, they can prompt ChatGPT for more detailed information, such as:
Write a social media post from an agent offering helpful tips and advice for buying a home. 
ChatGPT‚Äôs response:
Attention first-time home buyers! The home buying process can be overwhelming, but with the right knowledge and preparation, it can also be an exciting and rewarding experience. Here are a few tips to help make your home buying journey a success:

Get pre-approved for a mortgage before you start searching for a home. This will give you a better idea of your price range and help you make an offer more quickly when you find the right home.
Make a list of must-haves and nice-to-haves for your new home. Prioritize your needs and wants so you can focus your search on homes that meet your criteria. 
Hire a professional real estate agent who has experience in the area you are looking to buy. They can provide you with local market knowledge and help you navigate the buying process.
Be prepared to move quickly when you find the right home. In a competitive market, you need to be ready to make an offer as soon as you find the perfect property.
Don‚Äôt forget the home inspection! It‚Äôs important to have a professional inspect the home before you close to make sure you know what you are buying.

Buying a home can be stressful but with the right mindset and with the right professional help, you will find your dream home. Let‚Äôs work together to make your dream home a reality. #HomeBuyingTips #FirstTimeHomeBuyer #RealEstateAdvice 
Refining that post is as easy as including a specific neighborhood, target demographic, and ‚Äî of course ‚Äî your personal contact information and branding. This step will be different for every agent ‚Äî even between a single agent‚Äôs marketing campaigns.
Related article:
Career Coach: social media tips

Blogs
Blogs demonstrate an agent‚Äôs expertise in a particular area of real estate.
An agent may post their blog to their agent website, another hosting platform or both. Blogs are similar to social media marketing since many platforms are free and yield valuable exposure to the agent from both past and new clients.
An agent can control the tone of a ChatGPT-created blog by splitting the task up into smaller parts and editing for language between each. For instance, an agent might refine their strategy by asking the chatbot to:

come up with ideas for new blogs and manually select your most valuable topics;
draft an outline for a blog which targets a specific demographic or area; and
write full-length informative blogs, supplemented with your personal experience.

This is particularly effective for agents providing niche services, since less content (and competition) exists in smaller markets. Agents can still query the chatbot in this way to provide ideas on blog topics for that specialty. For example, an agent might prompt:
Come up with some blog ideas for a real estate agent in Los Angeles who specializes in commercial property for investors.
ChatGPT‚Äôs response:

‚ÄúThe Top Commercial Real Estate Markets in Los Angeles for Investors‚Äù
‚ÄúWhy Los Angeles is a Smart Choice for Commercial Real Estate Investment‚Äù
‚ÄúThe Pros and Cons of Different Types of Commercial Properties for Investment‚Äù
‚ÄúThe Importance of Due Diligence in Commercial Real Estate Investment‚Äù
‚ÄúThe Role of a Real Estate Agent in a Commercial Property Investment‚Äù
‚ÄúThe Benefits of Working with a Commercial Real Estate Specialist in Los Angeles‚Äù
‚ÄúThe Impact of COVID-19 on the Los Angeles Commercial Real Estate Market‚Äù
‚ÄúCommercial Property Management Tips for Investors‚Äù
‚ÄúHow to Identify and Evaluate Income-producing Commercial Properties in Los Angeles‚Äù
‚ÄúThe Future of Commercial Real Estate in Los Angeles: Trends to Watch‚Äù

Related article:
Career Coach: marketing yourself as a brand

Email
Unlike blogs and social media, email marketing is a more direct and reliable way of maintaining relationships with past and prospective clients.
Time-tested content creation ideas for your real estate marketing emails include:

advertising listings of properties;
solicitations to new potential clients;
upcoming events and open houses;
real estate news and market trends;
home maintenance and finance tips;
emails related to a client‚Äôs transactions, such as reminders and follow-ups; and
seasonal and holiday messages.

Just as with social media outlets, ChatGPT helps you generate email marketing ideas or helps you write the content with prompts. When prompted with:
Write an email marketing campaign from a Fresno real estate agent. Make the email message related to Memorial Day.
ChatGPT responds:
Dear [Name],
As Memorial Day approaches, we are reminded of the sacrifices made by our military heroes and their families. As a real estate agent in Fresno, I am honored to help those who have served our country find their dream homes.
This Memorial Day, I want to extend a special offer to all active and retired military personnel. If you are in the market to buy or sell a home, please contact me and I will work hard to ensure you receive the best deal possible.
As a Fresno real estate expert, I have a deep understanding of the local market and can help you navigate the buying or selling process with ease. I am committed to providing outstanding service and ensuring that your real estate experience is as stress-free as possible.
In honor of Memorial Day, I am also offering a complimentary home staging consultation for any active or retired military personnel who list their home with me by June 15th. This consultation will help you showcase your home in its best light and increase its appeal to potential buyers.
If you have any questions or would like to schedule a consultation, please don‚Äôt hesitate to contact me. I am here to help you find your dream home and to honor those who have served our country.
Sincerely,
[Your Name]
Real Estate Agent in Fresno
Related article:
Career Coach: your guide to mass marketing emails

Agent website
Ultimately, your professional website is the only platform you control 100%. With social media mostly free, real estate professionals of all specialties often overlook this facet of their digital footprint.
Consider these examples of effective content for your agent website:

your biography;
reviews from past clients;
press releases on successful sales or other professional achievements;
videos displaying your brand and services;
property listings; and
neighborhood information.

Like blog posts, press releases show off your expertise and experience in your service area. Try this ChatGPT prompt for a press release covering a home sale in San Francisco, California:
Write me, a real estate agent, a press release for a $1.4 million home I sold in San Francisco. 
ChatGPT‚Äôs response:
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
San Francisco Real Estate Agent Sells $1.4 Million Home
San Francisco, CA ‚Äì [Your name], a local real estate agent, is proud to announce the successful sale of a stunning $1.4 million home in the heart of San Francisco. The property, located at [address], boasts [number] bedrooms, [number] bathrooms, and [square footage] of living space, making it a perfect fit for a growing family or stylish urban retreat.
The home features high-end finishes and luxurious amenities, including [list of amenities]. The open-concept floor plan, large windows, and private backyard make it perfect for indoor-outdoor living and entertaining.
The home was on the market for only [number of days] before it received an offer, which was accepted by the seller. The property attracted multiple offers from eager buyers, demonstrating the high demand for high-end homes in San Francisco.
‚ÄúI am thrilled to have been able to assist the sellers in finding a buyer for their beautiful home,‚Äù said [Your name], the listing agent. ‚ÄúThe high demand for luxury homes in San Francisco is a testament to the city‚Äôs desirability and the strength of the local real estate market.‚Äù
[Your name] is an experienced and dedicated real estate agent who specializes in luxury homes and properties in San Francisco. If you‚Äôre interested in buying or selling a high-end property in the city, please contact [Your name] at [phone number] or [email address]. 
Contact:
[Your name]
[Your company name]
[phone number]
[email address]
Editor‚Äôs note ‚Äî This is a prototype press release and needs to be tailored to the specifics of the property and terms of sale. Check with your broker for permission to post a press release when the sale has not yet closed. 
Related article:
Career Coach: a website for every agent

Lead generation
ChatGPT is no stranger to the elevator pitch. Agents can leverage ChatGPT to woo new clients by prompting it to craft a killer introduction.
For example, an agent gives the following directions:
Act like a real estate salesperson. Write a sales pitch for a seller and let them know you can do a complete comparative market analysis to find the best price for their property.
And ChatGPT responds:
Hello, are you thinking of selling your property? I am a professional real estate salesperson and I can help you get the best price for your home. One of the first steps in the process is to do a complete comparative market analysis. This will give us a clear understanding of the current market conditions and help us to determine the best price for your property.
I have access to the latest data and trends in the market, and I will use this information to create a customized marketing plan that will target the right buyers for your home. I also have a network of contacts and resources that will help to ensure that your property is seen by as many potential buyers as possible. 
I will work closely with you throughout the entire process to ensure that you get the best price for your home and that the transaction goes smoothly. My goal is to make this process as stress-free as possible for you, so you can focus on your next move.
If you‚Äôre interested, I would love to schedule a meeting with you to discuss how I can help you get the best price for your property. Thank you for your time.
Recruiting agents
As the public‚Äôs interest in real estate wanes during periods of high prices and tight credit, brokers can use ChatGPT to help recruit agents and automate the tedious writing required of the hiring process.
A broker writes these directions:
I‚Äôm a real estate broker looking to hire an unlicensed employee who will become an agent. The candidate should have these qualities: a positive, energetic attitude, self-motivated, disciplined, consistent, knowledgeable of sales, willingness to learn, and adaptable. Write a job ad that will attract this type of hire and that highlights my diligence to train the right candidate.
And ChatGPT responds:
Are you a positive, energetic and self-motivated individual looking for a career in real estate? We are a growing real estate brokerage looking for an unlicensed candidate to join our team as a finder before obtaining their license and becoming an agent.
As a member of our team, you will have the opportunity to learn the industry from the ground up and help us find properties for our clients while working towards obtaining your license. We are looking for someone who is disciplined, consistent, knowledgeable of sales, and willing to learn and adapt.
We provide comprehensive training and support to ensure that you have the knowledge and skills needed to succeed in this exciting and rewarding industry. Our team is dedicated to helping our agents achieve their goals and reach their full potential.
Key Responsibilities:

Learn the process of buying and selling real estate
Build and maintain relationships with clients
Help clients find properties that meet their needs
Continuously improve your knowledge and skills

Qualifications:

Positive, energetic attitude
Self-motivated and disciplined
Consistent and adaptable
Willingness to learn and grow

If you are looking for a career in real estate and possess the above qualities, we would love to hear from you. Don‚Äôt miss out on this opportunity to jumpstart your real estate career and take the first step towards becoming a licensed agent. Apply today and let‚Äôs work together to reach your full potential!
Of course, brokers can further refine their query to attract candidates with the desired skills and specialties.
Related article:
CalPaces for Recruiting: Soliciting prospective hires

Drawbacks and limitations
Despite its potential, natural language processing models aren‚Äôt foolproof. A few notable drawbacks and limitations to ChatGPT include:

the quality of its answers (output) depends on the detail you include in the directions you enter (input);
authoritative-sounding responses may contain incorrect information or unlawful advice;
limited knowledge of events or trends after 2021;
a tendency to overuse specific words and phrases; and
not requesting clarification when it doesn‚Äôt understand user prompts, leading to wild guesses and inaccuracies.

Due to the chatbot‚Äôs inclination to give false (but accurate sounding) information, agents need to verify the response and edit to remove inaccuracies.
AI empowers smaller agents and brokers to do more with less. Agents with the knowledge (but not the capital) to attract clients and close transactions are best positioned to benefit from this revolutionary tech.
